title: Disco Sour
method: Dry shake, then wet shake. Fine strain into a coupette.
pro_tip: The blend of Falernum, Benedictine and apricot-infused pisco gives this a velvety body and tropical funk. Use with confidence once staff reach Level 3.
did_you_know: This is a neo-classic — not found in century-old books but gaining popularity in high-end bars with creative menus.

title: Tequila Paloma
ingredients: Pomelo Pink & Pepper Tonic or soda: 60ml
method: Build in a highball with ice, stir, and top with tonic or soda.
pro_tip: Add a pinch of salt to highlight the peppery reposado and citrus.
did_you_know: Paloma is the national drink of Mexico — more popular than the Margarita locally!

title: Royal Kir
method: Build in a flute. Add sloe gin first, then top with chilled prosecco.
pro_tip: Pour prosecco slowly down the inside of the flute to preserve bubbles.
did_you_know: The Royal Kir is a sparkling version of the traditional Kir cocktail, which uses crème de cassis and white wine.

title: Sundance
method: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
pro_tip: Balancing rye spice, rum warmth, and bitter liqueurs — a riff on the Connaught’s Everglow.
did_you_know: Cynar is an artichoke-based amaro, bringing vegetal depth to many contemporary cocktails. In this case the seeming overkill in ingredients really pays off and creates a rare but unique and surprisingly round finish.

title: Fogcutter
method: Shake with ice, strain into a highball glass, float sherry on top.
pro_tip: Layering the fino on top preserves its crisp dryness before blending with the rich body below.
did_you_know: The Fogcutter is a tiki classic invented in the 1940s — known as ‘the Long Island Iced Tea of the tropics.’

title: The Dirty Martini
method: Stir over ice and strain into a chilled martini glass.
pro_tip: Ask how dirty they want it — more brine = saltier, murkier.
did_you_know: The Dirty Martini was created in 1901 when bartender John O’Connor added olive brine to a traditional Martini. How dirty can youn go? Beware of customers requesting ludicrous amounts of olives - this is not part of your five a day!

title: Mezcal Paloma
ingredients: Pomelo Pink & Pepper Tonic or soda: 60ml
method: Build in a Collins glass over ice, stir gently. Top with tonic (or soda depending on availability).
pro_tip: Balance the grapefruit and agave — Mezcal’s smoky note can dominate if unbalanced.
did_you_know: A Paloma is more commonly drunk than a Margarita in Mexico. The mezcal twist adds richness and modern flair.

title: Gin Fizz
method: Shake with ice and strain into a Collins glass. Top with soda.
pro_tip: Fizzes are classic summer refreshers — chill all components for maximum sparkle.
did_you_know: The Gin Fizz was so popular in 1880s New Orleans that bars hired teams of shaker boys to keep up with demand.

title: Flint
method: Build over ice in a highball glass. Gently stir to integrate.
pro_tip: This is a layered flavour bomb: herbal, fruity, and spicy from the tonic. Serve cold and bright.
did_you_know: Inspired by the mineral and fruity contrast found in Flint terroirs, this drink plays off the complex mid-tones of chartreuse and melon.

title: The Whiskey Sour
method: Dry shake without ice, then shake again with ice. Fine strain into a chilled coupette.
pro_tip: Dry shaking helps emulsify egg white for the perfect foam — a hallmark of a well-executed sour.
did_you_know: One of the oldest cocktail families, the sour template (spirit + citrus + sweet) is found in dozens of drinks across cultures and its simple ratios have become the backbone of modern mixology. Some things will never change. Perfect this drink, present it right and you win the hearts of even the harshest critics.

title: The Margarita
method: Shake vigorously and fine strain into a coupette or rocks glass with optional salt rim.
garnish: Dehydrated lime wheel or salt rim
pro_tip: Ocho’s peppery profile adds bright spice to the traditional Margarita.
did_you_know: The Margarita’s origin is contested — some credit it to Tijuana in the 1930s, others to Texas in the 1940s. I just think it imply belongs in my mouth and can live in there rent free forever.

title: In the Woods
method: Shake hard and fine strain into a chilled coupette.
pro_tip: Batching the cordial in-house lets you control sugar and acidity — a true Level 3 showcase.
did_you_know: Inspired by the ‘Mysterious Woodlands’ style — earthy, deep, slightly sweet with a hint of wild.

title: The Classic Negroni
method: Stir well with ice in a Japanese stirring glass for dramatic effect - however this concoction should be “thrown” to aerate and add smoothness to this ever-bold drink. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, ideally one big cube.
garnish: Orange peel, expressed and stuck to the side, like a rabbit's ear.
pro_tip:
Tanqueray’s bold juniper works beautifully with Cocchi’s bitter-sweet complexity.
Stir until the liquid clings slightly to the glass.
did_you_know: The Negroni originated in Florence around 1919 when Count Camillo Negroni requested his Americano be made stronger. It’s now the world’s go-to aperitivo (or fuel for next-day dread)

title: The Caipirinha
method: Muddle 4 lime wedges with sugar in a rocks glass, add crushed ice, pour cachaça, cap shake and serve.
pro_tip: Use fresh limes and soft brown sugar for the most authentic flavour. Only use solid, thick glassware for this!
did_you_know: The national drink of Brazil, Caipirinha’s name comes from ‘caipira’, meaning a person from the countryside. It is, simply put, something that encapsulates long tradition and simplicity. The cap shake makes it very fun to make.

title: The Gibson Martini
method: Stir with ice, strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
pro_tip: Keep onions fresh and chilled — they are the signature of this savory Martini variation.
did_you_know: The Gibson is thought to be created by San Francisco businessman Walter D. K. Gibson in the late 19th century, who preferred an onion to an olive. Some say the idea of the cocktail onion as a garnish came from a cunning diplomat, who liked to stay sharp by adding an onion to be able to recognize his drink out of many on a tray being delivered on a tray amidst many, which in fact was just water.  Cunning, though I believe he would have been a much better diplomat with gin and vermouth in his system.

title: Mezcalita
method: Shake and fine strain into a rocks glass over ice.
pro_tip: Mezcal and grapefruit are natural partners — keep the syrup light to let the spirit shine.
did_you_know: This is a smoky cousin to the Margarita, increasingly popular on modern menus.

title: Miso Butter Old Fashioned
method: Stir thoroughly over ice and strain into a rocks glass with large ice cube.
pro_tip: Miso infusion adds umami — not for everyone, but bold and rich. Stir gently to preserve aromatics.
did_you_know: Butter-washed spirits are a modern bartending trend that add texture and subtle savoury depth.

title: Yuzu Negroni
method: Stir over ice until chilled. Strain over fresh ice into a rocks glass.
pro_tip: Choya Yuzu adds a soft, floral-citrus profile that lifts the bitterness of Campari.
did_you_know: This is a modern Japanese riff on the classic Negroni — yuzu is a citrus fruit that tastes like a cross between grapefruit and mandarin.

title: Negroni Spagliato
method: Build in a wine glass or rocks glass over ice and lift gently with a bar spoon.
pro_tip: Great for Negroni lovers seeking a lighter, sparkling alternative.
did_you_know: The name means ‘mistaken’ in Italian — a bartender accidentally swapped gin for Prosecco, and history was made. One of the most iconic mistakes ever made and one of the few ones we have very little to complain about. It makes an otherwise bold “drinker’s drink’ somewhat sophisticated.

title: The Amaretto Sour
method: Reverse dry-shake. Shake all ingredients without ice, then shake again with ice. Fine strain into a coupette, though some prefer it on the rocks.
pro_tip: Adding a bold rye whiskey like Rittenhouse offsets the sweetness of the Amaretto and gives structure.
did_you_know: The Amaretto Sour has enjoyed a revival — especially when made in this modern whiskey-laced style, inspired by Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s version, which replaces overbearing sweetness with a sophisticated attitude. It is nothing short of genius - there really is no need to add sugar to anything based on Amaretto, instead add sharp boldness of an overproof bourbon and you will win the amateur’s and connoisseurs heart. Make sure to observe the reactions.

title: Tommy's Margarita
method: Shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
pro_tip: Use fresh lime juice and high-quality agave syrup for the best balance.
did_you_know: Tommy’s Margarita was created in the early 1990s in San Francisco as a simpler, sweeter variation of the classic Margarita — omitting triple sec in favour of agave syrup.

title: Garden Fizz
method: Shake with ice and strain into a highball or Collins. Top with soda.
pro_tip: Pre-chill glassware and shake hard to make up for the lack of alcohol “burn” — this keeps the texture crisp and lively.
did_you_know: Seedlip was the first non-alcoholic spirit brand to reach global acclaim. Garden 108 uses peas and herbs as base botanicals — a bartender’s friend for N/A menus.

title: The Classic Daiquiri
method: Hard shake all ingredients with ice and fine strain into a chilled glass.
glassware: Coupette, though I believe a Nick and Nora makes it look slicker.
pro_tip: Balance is everything: adjust lime and syrup depending on your rum’s sweetness, the Planteray has beautiful, subtle, notes of vanilla which elevate this concoction and add true sophistication. El Dorado (not in our repertoire, sadly) is my absolute favorite but do take note and get yourself a bottle of El Dorado and try it yourself. If you (or your customer) are into a more candy approach, try to sweeten this drink with some agave syrup instead of simps - careful with dosage - but the results are likely to blow their mind if you have a sweet tooth.
did_you_know:
The Daiquiri was invented in Cuba and famously loved by Ernest Hemingway, although he preferred a sugarless version with grapefruit juice - which frankly isn’t very nice. We’re here to enjoy drinks!

As you all know I am a massive fan of this drink and even though a hard purist, I do like the idea of some variations of this concoction, in particular the Rhubarb and Strawberry riff.
Replacing the sugar with our rhubarb and strawberry cordial, this drink can actually be elevated to another level and bodes well with some fruity additives. Be aware of its natural fragility and elegance. Getting the proportions wrong can easily turn this into a nightmare in a cup!

title: The Wet Martini
method: Stir thoroughly with plenty of ice until well chilled and slightly diluted. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora.
pro_tip: A ‘wet’ Martini uses a higher proportion of vermouth. It’s smoother, more aromatic, and more approachable for Martini newcomers.
did_you_know: Winston Churchill famously preferred his Martini bone dry — but the wet version is now making a comeback as palates evolve. The difference is subtle, it’s still booze stirred with booze. Some may even say that … how did I get this drunk? I have seen battle hardened drinkers meet the creator with this surprisingly smooth concoction. Like most Martinis, the liquid should be chilled to sub-zero, which makes the pour a true experience. The viscosity of the liquid changes and you will feel like a true alchemist if done right.

title: Classic Daiquiri
method: Shake hard with ice and fine strain into a chilled coupette or Nick & Nora.
pro_tip: Balance is everything: the sugar and lime should elevate the rum, not hide it. Adjust ratios slightly for guest preference.
did_you_know: Invented in Cuba and famously favoured by Hemingway, the Daiquiri is a template cocktail — the basis for countless tropical classics.

title: Reverse Adonis
method: Shake with ice and fine strain into a chilled N&N.
pro_tip: Shaking highlights the lighter florals of the rosé vermouth and gives the drink a lively texture.
did_you_know: The original Adonis dates back to the 1880s and was named after a Broadway musical. This version inverts it with a smoky twist.

title: Spiced Sour
method: Dry shake, then shake again with ice. Fine strain into a coupette.
pro_tip: Great non-alcoholic option with all the ceremony of a classic sour. Texture is everything.
did_you_know: Seedlip was the world’s first distilled non-alcoholic spirit, designed to bring sophistication to alcohol-free options.

title: Tequila Rhubarb Sour
method: Reverse dry shake and fine strain into a chilled coupette.
pro_tip: Reverse dry shake ensures maximum foam and tight texture for egg white sours.
did_you_know:
Cazcabel’s earthy agave profile pairs well with sharp fruit like rhubarb, making this a perfect spring menu item. The inspiration for this concoction came, of course, from the Connaught. The craft going into making the cordial is immense but the result is incredible. Also, the side product of making the cordial modifier for this drink makes an incredibly tasty sorbet - which some of you may have enjoyed before ;-)
The base of this riff is also very suitable for slushies!

title: Tommy’s Margarita
method: Shake vigorously with ice. Fine strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
garnish: Dehydrated lime wheel or expressed lime zest
pro_tip: Use fresh lime juice — bottled alternatives dull the agave’s natural brightness. Shake hard for aeration.
did_you_know: Tommy’s Margarita replaces triple sec with agave syrup, invented at Tommy’s Mexican Restaurant in San Francisco — it’s now the global gold standard for a clean Margarita.

title: The Perfect Manhattan
method: Stir until properly diluted and silky. Julip strain into a chilled coupe.
garnish: Maraschino cherry, orange peel aromatised and discarded
pro_tip: The “Perfect” Manhattan uses both sweet and dry vermouths for a layered profile. Stir carefully to avoid over-dilution. Pour from hight - it adds drama to the process but also aerates the mixture, making it much smoother.
did_you_know: The Manhattan dates back to 1870s New York — its rye roots give it a spicy backbone loved by purists. It used to be my go-to just to get to the maraschino cherry as quickly as possible. Now I like to savor the moment and the three sips to get to the cherry. Sometimes two.

title: French Rubi
method: Build in a wine glass or flute. Stir gently to integrate.
garnish: Rhubarb ribbon or mint sprig suggested
pro_tip: If prosecco is too fizzy, stir gently or use a dash of soda to balance. This drink’s success lies in flavour harmony — not sparkle.
did_you_know: Pastis (aniseed liqueur) and rhubarb are rarely paired — this high-concept drink highlights flavour over fizz, making it ideal for staff R&D or special menu drops.

title: The Old Fashioned
method: Stir thoroughly with ice and strain over a single large cube in a rocks glass.
pro_tip: Use cold, dense ice to control dilution. Brown sugar syrup adds rich depth vs. white, squeezing the peel over the drink will release its oils and therefore a distinct aroma into the drink, some gently wipe the rim of the glass with it.
did_you_know: Dating back to the early 1800s, the Old Fashioned is often cited as the original cocktail.

title: Bitters & Smoke
method: Stir in mixing glass, strain into a chilled Nick & Nora
pro_tip: Stirring preserves the integrity of bitters and brings out complexity in smoky elements.
did_you_know: This modern bitter-sour hybrid balances amaro richness with mezcal’s earthiness — great for adventurous palates.

title: The Pisco Sour
method: Reverse dry shake, then shake with ice and fine strain into a coupette.
garnish: Bitters dots or swirl on foam.
pro_tip: Use a reverse dry shake to maximise foam without over-diluting the pisco, just a swift dash of orange bitters in the tin will make a difference that goes a long way, separating a “classic classic” into a memory - people will come back for more. Share the love.
did_you_know: This Peruvian classic dates back to the early 1900s and is a national drink with disputed origin claims - therefore no more details about origins and disputed claims. It is, hands down, one of the most universally loved drinks, by amateurs and connoisseurs alike. It has a degree of boldness but is, simultaneously, surprisingly sophisticated.

title: Fig Negroni
method: Stir with care over ice. Serve on fresh ice in a rocks glass.
garnish: Dehydrated fig (if available) or orange peel
pro_tip: Balance is key — the fig liqueur must accent, not overwhelm. Tanqueray’s punchy gin base holds up well.
did_you_know: Considered a riff on the Negroni, the fig and cocoa combo adds deep complexity. Ideal for guests seeking something adventurous but familiar.

title: Apricot Gin Fizz
method: Shake with ice and strain into a Collins glass. Top with soda.
pro_tip: Perfect balance of sweet fruit and bright citrus — ideal in warm weather.
did_you_know: This is a twist on the classic Gin Fizz, swapping sugar for fruit syrup for depth and colour.

title: The Martinez
method: Stir with ice until chilled and balanced. Julep strain into a Nick & Nora.
garnish: Lemon twist (+ express and discard orange peel)
pro_tip: Think of the Martinez as a bridge between a Manhattan and a Martini — the Maraschino gives it elegant sweetness. Stir with care, if you get a hint of gummy bear you know that you have hit the spot. Some say to add a drop of orange bitters in the ice water when chilling the glass is the key to an outstanding result.
did_you_know: Widely considered the precursor to the Martini, the Martinez dates back to the mid-1800s and showcases how gin-based cocktails evolved. It is a bold and simultaneously fragile masterpiece. It encapsulates everything that a sweet tooth hates, and everything they love - and vice versa. I would go as far as to say that this particular cocktail made me more curious about cocktails in general. En masse, a great way to endure even the most tedious of company. In moderation, a great way to start an evening. Or finish it.

title: The Dry Martini
method: Stir over ice until well chilled, ideally reaching sub-zero temperature. Julep strain from hight into a chilled Nick & Nora or Martini glass. Always ask guest for their spirit preference (vodka or gin).
pro_tip: Using quality ice and a proper chill on the glass makes a huge difference in clarity and texture.
did_you_know: The Dry Martini became a symbol of elegance in the 20th century and has hundreds of variations — including the Dirty, Gibson, and Vesper.

title: The Paper Plane
method: Shake hard with ice and fine strain into a Nick & Nora or coupe.
pro_tip: Use a tight shake to ensure full integration — equal parts require perfect balance in acidity and bitterness!
did_you_know: Created by Sam Ross in 2008, the Paper Plane is modern cocktail royalty, named after the M.I.A. track. Balanced, bitter, and addictive. Get this right, using the right method and impeccable precision and you have people coming back for more.
